page.title: 19 Flora and Fauna at Radcot
page.content: The whole area is rich in natural habitats; there are well established hedges, river banks, a lake and many small areas of woodland. In the hedgerows a profusion of wild flowers grow among the shrubs and trees. Owing to the maintainance of the hedges, common wild plants, which are disappearing elsewhere are flourishing. Valerian, Meadow Sweet, Balsam and Hop thrive amongst Maple, Dog Rose, Bramble and Blackthorn. Due to the great length of hedge and wood edge there is a good variety of bird life to be seen. Winter flocks of finches and thrushes feed on the berries; woodpeckers and tits feed in the trees while flocks of Lapwing, crows and gulls feed in the fields on grubs and slugs. The barns and old trees provide homes for owls and hawks.
